[[File:Baha'i House of Worship, Kampala, Uganda.jpg|thumb|Baha'i House of Worship, Kampala, Uganda]] The '''Bahá'í Faith in Uganda''' started to grow in 1951 and four years later there were 500 Bahá'ís in 80 localities, including 13 Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly|Local Spiritual Assemblies]], representing 30 tribes, and had dispatched 9 [[pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]] to other African locations.<ref name="africa">{{cite web | last =Hassall | first = Graham | title = References to Africa in the Bahá'í Writings | work = Asian/Pacific Collection | publisher = Asia Pacific Bahá'í Studies | date = 2003-08-26 | url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_africa_bahai_writings | accessdate = 2008-06-21}}</ref> Following the reign of [[Idi Amin]] when the Bahá'í Faith was banned and the murder of Bahá'í [[Hand of the Cause]] [[Enoch Olinga]] and his family,<ref name="enoch">{{Cite web |first=N. Richard |last=Francis |title=Olinga, Enoch |year=1998 |website=Bahá'í Library |url=http://bahai-library.com/francis_olinga_biography}}</ref> the community continues to grow though estimates of the population range widely from 19,000 to 105,000 and the community's involvements have included diverse efforts to promote the welfare of the Ugandan people. The [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying on [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]) estimated about 78500.<ref name="WCE-05">{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-07-04}}</ref>
==Early phase== {{Bahá'í sidebar}}
===`Abdu'l-Bahá's Tablets of the Divine Plan=== [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] wrote a series of letters, or [[tablets (religious)|tablets]], to the followers of the religion in the [[United States]] in 1916–1917; these letters were compiled together in the book ''[[Tablets of the Divine Plan]]''. The eighth and twelfth of the tablets mentioned [[Africa]] and were written on April 19, 1916, and February 15, 1917, respectively. Publication however was delayed in the United States until 1919—after the end of the [[World War I|First World War]] and the [[Spanish flu]]. The tablets were translated and presented by [[Mirza Ahmad Sohrab]] on April 4, 1919, and published in ''[[Star of the West (Bahá'í magazine)|Star of the West]]'' magazine on December 12, 1919.<ref>{{cite book | last = Abbas | first = `Abdu'l-Bahá |others=Mirza Ahmad Sohrab (trans. and comments) | title = Tablets, Instructions and Words of Explanation |date=April 1919 | url =http://bahai-library.com/abdulbaha_tablets_instructions_explanation}}</ref> `Abdu'l-Bahá mentions Bahá'ís traveling "…especially from America to Europe, Africa, Asia and Australia, and travel through Japan and China. Likewise, from Germany teachers and believers may travel to the continents of America, Africa, Japan and China; in brief, they may travel through all the continents and islands of the globe"<ref name="ToDP8">{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan|edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, IL |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-8.html.iso8859-1 | pages = 47–59 |origyear = 1916–17}}</ref> and " …the anthem of the oneness of the world of humanity may confer a new life upon all the children of men, and the tabernacle of universal peace be pitched on the apex of America; thus Europe and Africa may become vivified with the breaths of the Holy Spirit, this world may become another world, the body politic may attain to a new exhilaration…."<ref>{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, IL|isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-12.html.iso8859-1 | pages = 82–89 |origyear = 1916–17}}</ref>
===Connections and development=== An early instance of contact between Uganda and the Bahá'í Faith came in September 1946 when Ugandan Dr. Ernest Kalibala, one of Uganda's first PhDs<ref>[http://archive.lib.msu.edu/DMC/African%20Journals/pdfs/Utafiti/vol2no1/aejp002001004.pdf Professionalism and Unionism in the teaching service: The development of teacher' organizations in Uganda], by AK. Tiberondwa, Utafiti Journal, vol 2, no. 1,</ref> then associated with the UN, gave a talk at the New York Bahá'í Center.<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/286654/ugandan_earnest_kalibala_talk_at_bahai/ African to address meeting], The New York Age, 21 September 1946, page 4</ref> Particular plans to bring the religion to Uganda began in 1950 involving the cooperation of American, British, [[Bahá'í Faith in Egypt|Egyptian]], and Persian Bahá'í communities<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The African Teaching Project |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1951 | page =1 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=395 | issue = 241}}</ref> and reached a level of coordination and detail that materials were translated into languages widely used in Africa before pioneers reached Africa.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Africa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1950 | page =9 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=367 | issue = 238}}</ref> On August 3, 1951 Mr. and Mrs. [[Hand of the Cause#Second contingent, appointed 29 February 1952 by Shoghi Effendi|Músá Banání]], Mrs. Violette and Mr. [[Ali Nakhjavani]], of [[Iran]], with their baby daughter [[Bahiyyih Nakhjavani|Bahiyyih]], and Mr. Philip Hainsworth arrived in [[Kampala]]. Banání was an adult convert to the religion during World War I<ref name="BN488">{{cite magazine | title = Hand of the Cause of God Músá Banání |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1971 | page =2 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=07&page=930 | issue = 488}}</ref> from a Jewish background.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Músa Banání | work = | publisher = Find a Grave | url = http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GScid=2295282&GRid=34175447& | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-10-25}}</ref> After receiving the news that Hand of the Cause [[Louis George Gregory]] — [[Hands of the Cause]] are a select group of Bahá'ís who achieved a distinguished rank in service to the religion — had died previously on July 31, a commemorative meeting for Gregory was held in Kampala at which the five pioneers and Marguerite Preston (from [[Bahá'í Faith in Kenya|Kenya]]) were joined by twelve Africans. In October an observance of the birth of the [[Báb]] was the first to be held in the home of a [[Buganda]]n citizen of Uganda, with prayers said in [[Luganda]].<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Notes from "Africa News" |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1952 |pages=8–9 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=572 | issue = 238}}</ref> In December, the first two native Ugandans had converted to the Bahá'í Faith — Fred Bigabwa ([[Mutoro]] tribe) and Chrispin Kajubi ([[Buganda]] tribe).<ref name="uk">{{Cite news | last = Mughrab | first = Jan | title = Jubilee Celebration in Cameroon | periodical = Bahá'í Journal of the Bahá'í Community of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United Kingdom | volume=20 | issue=5 | year = 2004 | url = http://bahai-library.com/pdf/bjuk/bjuk_2004_jan-feb_v20_n5_7_Jubilee_Celebration_in_Cameroon.pdf | format = pdf | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> While Banání was on pilgrimage War War II veteran [[Enoch Olinga]] (of [[Iteso people|Iteso]] tribe) who had been attending classes taught by Nakhjavani in Kampala was the third Ugandan to become a Bahá'í and swore off alcohol though his [[alcoholism]] had already cost him his government job.<ref name="enoch"/> [[File:Languages of Uganda.png|thumb|250px|left|Ethnolinguistic map of Uganda.]] The first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] in the country was elected in April 1952 in Kampala. The members of the assembly were Fred Bigabwa, Chrispin Kajubi, Peter Musoke, Enoch Olinga, Mr and Mrs Músá Banání, Mr and Mrs Ali Nakhjavani and Philip Hainsworth.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Hainsworth | first = Philip | author-link = Philip Hainsworth | title = It All Began 50 Years Ago ... | journal = Bahá'í Journal of the Bahá'í Community of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United Kingdom | volume = 2001 | issue = May | date = May 2001 | url = http://bahai-library.com/pdf/bjuk/bjuk_2001_v18_no1-may_14_Our_History.pdf | format = pdf | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> These were soon joined by American pioneers, Mary and Reginald (Rex) Collison, in about May.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = International News; The British Isles |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1952 | page =12 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=606| issue = 256}}</ref> In early 1952, Músá Banání was also appointed as a [[Hand of the Cause]].<ref name="africa"/> In the summer of 1952 the Bahá'ís bought the first center for hosting meetings.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = International News; Africa; Opening of New Hazira |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1952 | page =4 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=642 | issue = 259}}</ref> By October 1952 there were 55 members of the religion including Olinga's father, living in 12 different localities and representing 9 different tribes: Ganda, Gishu, Gwero, Kabarasi, Kakamega, Luo, Sega, Teso, Toro. Six of them were women. Eighteen were in Kampala and 26 in Teso country. Like Olinga other Bahá'ís effected a change in character when converting to the religion and giving up alcoholism.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Unusual teachings activities in Uganda/ Extracts from letter to the Guardian from the British Africa Committee/ African Bahá'í Letter to British Committee |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1952 |pages=7–8 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=689 | issue = 262}}</ref> These joined the religion by conversion from Roman Catholic, Protestant and pagan backgrounds and the rural areas were organized into committees until Assemblies could be organized.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = International News; Uganda; Great Teaching Strides in Uganda |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1952 | page =12 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=694 | issue = 262}}</ref> In February 1953 the first inter-continental conference of four designated by the head of the religion was taking place in Kampala. On the program were Hands of the Cause (already appointed or not yet) [[Dorothy Beecher Baker]], [[`Alí-Akbar Furútan]], [[Ugo Giachery]], [[Hermann Grossman]], [[`Alí-Muhammad Varqá]], [[George Townshend (Bahá'í)|George Townshend]], and [[Dhikru'llah Khadem]] giving a wide variety of talks and classes across 7 days<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Jubilee Year… |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1953 | page =6 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=708 | issue = 263}}</ref> opened with a message from Shoghi Effendi read by Hand of the Cause [[Leroy Ioas]].<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The Guardian's Message to the first Intercontinental Conference |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1953 |pages=1–3 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=727| issue = 265}}</ref> By April nine more assemblies were elected<ref name="enoch"/> among a community of over two hundred ninety members of the religion, residing in twenty-five localities, and representative of twenty tribes.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Supplementary message to the Forty-Fifth Annual Convention|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1953 | page =3 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=757 | issue = 267}}</ref> In June 1953 the American pioneers Mr. and Mrs. Rex Collison moved to [[Ruanda-Urundi]] from Kampala.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = National Assembly; Second Pioneer effort|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1953 | page =2 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=956 | issue = 272}}</ref> In October 1953 Olinga went on to [[Bahá'í Faith in Cameroon|Cameroon]] and was honoured with the title [[Knight of Bahá'u'lláh]].<ref name="uk"/>
==Developing community==
Wide-scale growth in the religion across [[Sub-Sahara]]n Africa was observed to begin in the 1950s and extend in the 1960s.<ref name="UofC">{{cite web |title=Overview Of World Religions |work=General Essay on the Religions of Sub-Saharan Africa |publisher=Division of Religion and Philosophy, [[University of Cumbria]] |url=http://philtar.ucsm.ac.uk/encyclopedia/sub/geness.html |accessdate=2008-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071209082606/http://philtar.ucsm.ac.uk/encyclopedia/sub/geness.html |archivedate=2007-12-09 }}</ref> After the conference in February 1953 [[William Sears (Bahá'í)|Bill and Marguerite Sears]] arrived in September 1953 visiting from Johannesburg for an extended stay into October giving many classes and traveling to many villages.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Report from Uganda |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1954 |pages=10–15 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=1058 | issue = 280}}</ref> It was also during this time the first pioneer from Uganda went to [[Mwanza]], Tanganyika. In 1954 Uganda had 500 Bahá'ís in 80 localities, including 13 Local Spiritual Assemblies, representing 30 tribes, and had dispatched 9 pioneers to other African locations.<ref name="africa"/> In 1955 there were over 800 Bahá'ís having just added seventeen assemblies.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = New Assemblies in Africa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1955 | page =5 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=207 | issue = 295}}</ref> In 1956 Olinga was elected as Chairman of the North West regional Bahá'í [[National Spiritual Assembly]] and the Ugandan Bahá'í community came under the newly formed regional National Spiritual Assembly of Central & Eastern Africa,<ref name="sum">{{cite web | last = Hassall | first = Graham | title = Notes on Research on National Spiritual Assemblies | work = Asia Pacific Bahá'í Studies | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_nsas_years_formation | accessdate = 2008-05-04}}</ref> of which Nakhjavani was the Chairman<ref name="ali">{{Cite news | last = International Community | first = Bahá'í | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = Two members of Universal House of Justice leave after 40 years service | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 2003-04-29 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/206 | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref> and the Ugandan community alone topped 1000 members.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The Guardian's Message to the Forty-Eighth Annual Baha'i Convention; Enrollments in Virqin Territories |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1956 | page =4 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=318 | issue = 303}}</ref> The other members of the regional assembly over Uganda were [[Hainsworth, Philip|Philip Hainsworth]], Hassan Sabri, Oloro Epyeruj, Aziz Yazdi, Jalal Nakhjavani, Tito Wanantsusit, Sylvester Okurut, and Max Kenyerezi.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Kampala Convention Elects Regional National Assembly of Central and East Africa; Election of Assembly|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1956 |pages=8–9 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=363 | issue = 306}}</ref> In early 1957 Olinga attended the laying of the foundation stone of the first [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] of Africa (which was in Uganda) and in the fall he was appointed a [[Hand of the Cause]]<ref name="uk"/> and [[Knights of Bahá'u'lláh|Knight of Bahá'u'lláh]] Clare Gung, formerly of Germany, moved from Tanganyika to Uganda where she founded a multi-racial kindergarten nursery.<ref name="BN611">{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Uganda|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1982 |issn=0195-9212 | page =16 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=10&page=598| issue = 611}}</ref> Systems were initiated to deal with the rate of growth of the religion - weekend [[Bahá'í schools]] were set up for any Bahá'í who could attend and individuals who were judged to have a substantial understanding of the religion and were able to travel were selected for training as presenters who would then travel locally in their area to make presentations on many of the same themes.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Schools stimulate Growth of Faith |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1957 |pages=12–13 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=563| issue = 317}}</ref> By the summer of 1957 13 weekend schools had been held. It was believed these schools lent impetus to the continued growth of the religion in the area by empowering local members of the religion and the schools were repeated in 1958.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Training Course in Bubulo, Uganda, Prepares Teachers To Conduct Baha'i Weekend Schools |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1958 | page =12 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=896 | issue = 334}}</ref> And the same year regional and local assemblies were registered with the civil government.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = International News; Central and East Africa; Achieve two African goals |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1957 | page =6 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=593 | issue = 319}}</ref> In 1957 a lone Bahá'í, a member of the Tesa, Yokolamu Okello, reached the relatively remote and pagan region of [[Moroto Town|Moroto]] in [[Karamoja]] and in 1958 the first spiritual assembly was formed there.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Uganda Teaching Committee to Train Pagan-Area Pioneers for Teaching |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1960 | page =8 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=154 | issue = 356}}</ref> Conversions to the Bahá'í Faith in Uganda even reached into the prisons where [[Shoghi Effendi]], then head of the religion, responded to letters by encouraging the inmates to use their "stumbled" history not to become "embittered or defeated" but "determined to make it a means of purifying your natures, improving your characters, and enabling you to become better citizens in the future."<ref>{{cite web | last = Poirier | first = Prepared by Brent | title = Turn Your Back to the Darkness, and Your Face to Me | work = Unpublished Compilations | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | url = http://bahai-library.com/compilation_triumphing_over_weaknesses | accessdate = 2008-06-21 }}</ref> The quick growth of the religion in Uganda was attributed by Bahá'ís to the sincerity of their purpose and to the demonstrated lack of racial prejudice.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The Continent of Africa is Pre-Eminent|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1954 | page =5 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=1053 | issue = 280}}</ref>
===House of Worship=== In 1958 the land for the temple had to be bought in the name of three African Ugandan Bahá'ís rather than an institution directly foreign or domestic. These Bahá'ís were Joseph Mbogo, Erisha Kiwanuka and Max Kanyerezi who held the land in trust.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The Mother Temple of Africa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1958 |pages=9–10 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=720 | issue = 325}}</ref> The [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] in Uganda, named as the Mother Temple of Africa, is situated on [[Kikaya Hill]] on the outskirts of Kampala. At the ceremony of the laying of the foundation stone in 1958 Hands of the Cause [[Ruhiyyih Khanum]] and Músá Banání presented material gifts for the building - some soil from the inner-most [[Shrine of Bahá'u'lláh]] and the fortress of [[Maku, Iran|Maku]] where the [[Báb]] was imprisoned.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Relics Placed in Foundation |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1958 | page =10 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=721 | issue = 325}}</ref> The building was designed by [[Mason Remey]] and the green dome is made of fixed mosaic tiles from [[Italy]], the lower roof tiles are from [[Belgium]], and the colored glass in the wall panels was brought from [[Germany]].<ref name="UGPulse">{{Cite news | last = Rulekere | first = Gerald | title = Uganda's Bahá'í Temple - The Bahai Temple: Where nature, faith and artistic beauty reign | newspaper = UGPulse Uganda | date = 2006-11-07 | url =http://www.ugpulse.com/articles/daily/homepage.asp?ID=491 | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref> Nine massive columns, each two feet in diameter, support the great dome, itself forty-four feet in diameter at its base; while the two roofs are supported by two sets of twenty seven slightly smaller columns. The overall height is 127 ft., the internal diameter of the building is eighty four feet and the seating capacity is over 600. The inside of the dome is painted a pale blue; the rotunda, into which are set nine enormous windows and fifty-four small windows, all filled with green, amber and pale blue glass, is painted a brilliant white, while the columns and the lower walls are painted a very pale green. All this lends itself to an effect of lightness and airiness which is intensified by the large green and amber glass-filled grilles which stand on either side of the huge mvule doors.<ref name="Argus">{{cite magazine | title = Uganda Argus Publishes Supplement on Kampala Temple |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1961| page =4 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=210| issue = 360}}</ref>
The fifty-acre property includes the House of Worship, extensive gardens, a guest house, and an administrative center.<ref name="UGPulse"/> In 1960 the Ugandan government built an access road out to the site of the temple<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Buganda Government Builds Road for Temple |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1960 | page =7 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=129 | issue = 354}}</ref> and a Bugandan council of ministers came to see the building.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = International News Briefs |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1961 | page =7 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=195| issue = 359}}</ref> Observances of Bahá'í Holy days are held and regular services are normally held about 4 pm on Sunday afternoons.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Birthday of Baha'u'llah Celebrated by Believers in Vicinity of African Temple |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1962 | page =13 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=379 | issue = 370}}</ref> By the end of 1965 an estimated 50,000 visitors had come to the temple.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = News Briefs |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1965 | page =22 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=06&page=278 | issue = 417}}</ref> Both Hands of the Cause Enoch Olinga and Músá Banání are buried near the Temple.<ref name="enoch"/>
====Dedication==== [[File:Bahai-uganda.jpg|thumb|Practising Baha'is]] Festivities associated with the opening of the temple were wide-ranging through early 1961. The Ugandan government publication ''[[New Vision|Uganda Argus]]'' covered the history and description of the temple in the January 1961 issue<ref name="Argus"/> and interviews and stories ran on the Ugandan Broadcasting service on radio.<ref name="BN361">{{cite magazine | title = Hand of Cause 'Amatu'l-Baha Ruhiyyih Khanum Dedicates Mother Temple of Africa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1961 |pages=2–9 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=220| issue = 361}}</ref> Events on site began on the 13th with a unity feast with Hands of the Cause Musa Banani, John Robarts, Rahmatu'lláh Muhájir and Chairman of the regional assembly Ali Nakhkajvani and vice-chairman O]oro Epyeru giving talks. The temple was dedicated on 14th led by Hand of the Cause Ruhiyyih Khanum where there was a viewing of portraits of the Báb and Bahá'u'lláh. And the public inaugural service was held on the 15th. Over 1500 people attended.<ref name="BN361"/> Among the Bahá'ís were some 225 African Bahá'ís from Uganda, Kenya, Tanganyika, Ruanda Urundi, Ethiopia, Northern Rhodesia, Swaziland, and South Africa; some 90 Persian Baha'is, sixty-two of whom flew from Tehran; the British national assembly, the mother assembly to that of Central and East Africa, sent one believer from each of its regions - England, Scotland and Wales, as well as one from Ireland; the American national assembly sent one of its members, Amos Gibson, himself a pioneer among the American Indian peoples. Hand of the Cause Enoch Olinga was unable to attend due to [[History of Cameroon#Cameroon after independence|political turmoil in Cameroon]] Olinga was attempting to help them with. A choir, especially selected from among Kampala's singers and directed by Peter Wingard of [[Makerere College]] sang music<ref name="Argus"/> and readings offered were from the Old and New Testaments and the Qur'an, plus a number of prayers and readings from the Bahá'í writings in Arabic, Persian, Ateso, Swahili, Acholi, Luganda and English. Following the public meeting a reception was held for representatives of the Governor and the [[Kabaka of Buganda]], together with the Mayor of Kampala at which Ruhiyyih Khanum shared a story that Shoghi Effendi had traveled through the region in the early 1920s.<ref name="BN361"/> Following the dedication Ruhiyyih Khanum and chairman Nakhkajvani embarked on 15 days of visiting Bahá'ís through Uganda and Kenya including staying in their homes, dedicating two schools, ate native food, and were honored with traditional songs and dances. Khanum suggested repeatedly that the Ugandan's own folklore, their traditions and their native songs and music should not be discarded, but that in a society of unity in diversity they were to preserve and develop these as their contribution in enriching the spiritual and material life of human society as well as noting the equality of the sexes and that women should take equal part in administration of the religion.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Hand of Cause Visits African Villages |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1961 |pages=6–9 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=240 | issue = 362}}</ref>
===Intercontinental conferences===
====First conference==== In January 1958, soon after the death of Shoghi Effendi in November, another intercontinental conference was held in Kampala and attended by his widow Ruhiyyih Khanum.<ref name="BN327">{{cite magazine | title = Soul-Stirring Visit of Ruhiyyih Khanum Inspires Kampala Conference to Heights of Devotion to Faith |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1958 |pages=7–13 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=754 | issue = 327}}</ref> Though sorrowful at his death, there was a call to service in honor of his service. The conference had been initially planned for less than 400 attendees and was overwhelmed as news of over 300 Persians alone were coming. Ultimately some 950 Bahá'ís, six Hands of the Cause, a member of the [[International Bahá'í Council]], sixteen Auxiliary Board members, and representatives from eleven national spiritual assemblies (including those from the four African regional assemblies, those from the other national assemblies which had participated in campaign to bring the religion to sub-Saharan Africa - Britain, India, Iraq, Persia, and the United States - and those from Arabia and Japan), 450 African members, over 300 from Persia, two [[Knights of Bahá'u'lláh]] (one from the Pacific and one from the Arctic), and others from rest of the world were present at the formal convening of the conference as well as telegrams received from many other Hands of the Cause and 34 national assemblies arrived. Reportedly every hotel room was booked.<ref name="BN327"/> Ruhiyyih Khanum anointed most attendees with [[Rose oil|Attar of rose]] before being admitted into a viewing of relics of Bahá'u'lláh as well as a reproduction of a painting of him on the first day of the conference. Viewings were also held of a large map by Shoghi Effendi showing the progress of the religion, films of Shrines and gardens from the [[Bahá'í World Center]], as it existed then, as well as the Monument on the grave of Shoghi Effendi.<ref name="BN327"/> Some $280,000 was raised at the conference from a segment of the attendees for donation to the progress of the religion. The foundation stone for the Mother Temple of Africa was laid and relics in silk bags made by [[Bahiyyih Khánum]] were set in place (planned to be under the wall on that side of the Temple facing out across a grassy valley towards the Bahá'í [[Qiblih]].) Ruhiyyih Khanum then spent a day among the Tseo people - speaking to school groups, receiving guests, and visiting homes. She donated money for the reconstruction of a center that had been lost.<ref name="BN327"/>
====Second Conference==== Six conferences held in October 1967 around the world presented a viewing of a copy of the photograph of [[Bahá'u'lláh]] on the highly significant occasion commemorating the centennial of Bahá'u'lláh's writing of the ''[[Suriy-i-Mulúk]]'' (Tablet to the Kings), which [[Shoghi Effendi]] describes as "the most momentous Tablet revealed by Bahá'u'lláh".<ref name="bpg">{{cite book |first=Shoghi |last=Effendi |authorlink=Shoghi Effendi |year=1944 |title=God Passes By |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, US |isbn=0-87743-020-9 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/GPB/|page=171}}</ref> After a meeting in Edirne ([[Adrianople]]), Turkey, the [[Hands of the Cause]] travelled to the conferences, with each carrying a copy of the photograph of Bahá'ú'lláh. Hand of the Cause `Alí-Akbar Furútan conveyed this photograph to the Conference for Africa at Uganda.<!-- Wilmette -- Tarazu'llah Samandari(replacing Leroy Ioas who died; Sydney -- Ugo Giachery; Kampala -- 'Ali Akbar Furutan; Frankfurt -- Paul Haney; New Delhi -- Abul-Qasim Faizi; Panama -- Ruhiyyih Khanum--><ref>{{cite book | last = House of Justice | first = Universal | authorlink = Universal House of Justice | title = Wellspring of Guidance, Messages 1963–1968 | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | year = 1976 | location = Wilmette, Illinois | pages = 109–112 | url = http://bahai-library.com/uhj_wellspring_guidance | isbn = 0-87743-032-2 }}</ref> [[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony magazine]] covered the event.<ref>{{Cite news | last = McKenty | first = Beth | title = Baha'is Commemorate Predictions and Warnings of Founder; African Conference is the focal point of worldwide observance of religious group | magazine = Ebony | pages = 125–126, 128 | date = April 1968 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=Ec4DAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA124&pg=PA125#v=onepage&q= | accessdate = 2009-10-22 | publisher = Johnson Publishing Company | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> Ugandan radio, television and print media covered the events related to the conference as well.<ref name="BN441">{{cite magazine | title = Conference Imparts New Spirit of Courage |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1967 |pages=26–30 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=07&page=26 | issue = 441}}</ref> Some 400 Bahá'ís from twenty-four African countries gathered. Kolonerio Oule, chairman of the National Assembly for Uganda and Central Africa, opened the conference on the first day and Hands of the Cause `Alí-Akbar Furútan and Enoch Olinga began presentations and discussions about the history of the tablets and the range of who they were made for. The next day the new national center building on the same property as the temple was dedicated - it is a circular building having a round central auditorium surrounded by a group of offices, a library, archives, publishing, guest roams and kitchen. The third day William Masehla and speaker [[Helen Elsie Austin]] focused attention on the role of the individual in the progress of the religion.<ref name="BN441"/> That evening a public meeting of some 500 people was held followed by a reception for 250 people; efforts had focused invitations to government personnel, clergy, educational institutions and professional communities. [[Roger White (Bahá'í)|Roger White]] was a representative of the Canadian national Assembly which made a gift to the Bahá'ís of Uganda in the form of an illuminated tablet of the writings of the religion.<ref name="BN441"/>
===Other developments=== It was in 1958 that the Bahá'ís of Kampala contracted to reserve a segment of a cemetery for use by Bahá'ís.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Kampala Assembly Secures Land For a Baha'i Burial Ground |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1959 | page =8 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=928| issue = 336}}</ref> Weekend schools begun in 1958 continued through 1960 though classes now used chapters from ''Bahá'u'lláh and the New Era'' by [[John Esslemont]].<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Baha'is of 3 Central and East African Areas Attend Teather Training Course in Kampala |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1960 | page =12 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=170 | issue = 357}}</ref> In September 1961,<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Two Baha'i Primary Schools Opened in Uganda |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1961 | page =11 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=313 | issue = 366}}</ref> a number of permanent [[Bahá'í school]]s were set up—two Louis Gregory Bahá'í Schools, one in [[Tilling, Uganda|Tilling]], the home town of Olinga,<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Hainsworth-Fadaie | first = Zarin | title = Uganda Jubilee – a participant’s account | journal = Bahá'í Journal of the Bahá'í Community of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United Kingdom | volume = 2001 | issue = Nov/Dec | date = Nov–Dec 2001 | url = http://bahai-library.com/pdf/bjuk/bjuk_2001_v18_no6_nov-dec_8_Uganda_Jubilee.pdf| format = pdf | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> and the other in [[Dusai]]. Courses emphasized homecraft and child rearing mixed with presentations on the religion and men supported women taking the courses. News of the openings was covered in ''[[Jet (magazine)|Jet Magazine]]''.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Establish Bahai Faith Schools in Uganda | magazine = Jet | volume = 19 | issue = 26 | issn=0021-5996 | publisher = Johnson Publishing Company |page=24 | date = April 20, 1961 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=FLEDAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA3&dq=jet&pg=PA24#v=onepage&q= | accessdate = 2009-11-22 | author1 = Company, Johnson Publishing | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> The extraordinary number of enrollments in Uganda and Kenya had reached the point in late 1959 that the institution of the Hands of the Cause were noting there were not enough Bahá'ís to keep up with the work of checking the enrollments.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Hands of the Cause In the Holy Land Outline Latest Developments in World-Wide Spread of Faith |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=April 1960 | pages = 1–2 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=59 | issue = 350}}</ref> 1961 also saw the development of a Ugandan Bahá'í publishing trust.<ref name="stats">{{cite web | url = http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63&chapter=1#22 | title = The Bahá'í Faith: 1844–1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953–1963| author = [[Hands of the Cause]] | pages = 6, 25, 28, 119–125 }}</ref> Olinga was able to re-visit Uganda in June,<ref>{{cite magazine | title = International Council Recounts Victories; Rapid Advance in Teaching Reid |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1962 |pages=2–3 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=504 | issue = 378}}</ref> and again in August–September 1962 when he toured widely in Uganda speaking to many groups amounting to thousands of people about the religion before moving on to Kenya and Tanganyika and the Congo.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Hand of Cause Spurs Mass Conversion In Central and East Africa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1963 |pages=6–7 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=610| issue = 384}}</ref> As the monthly rate of growth reached into the hundreds, a goal of the Uganda Teaching Committee was of stimulating the individual assemblies and believers to assume increasing responsibility for weekend schools in their own villages so that traveling teachers could focus in other areas.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Victories Outweigh Hardships as Faith Advances in Central and East Africa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1962 |pages=8–9 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=390| issue = 371}}</ref> In September 1962 [[Milton Obote]], then Prime Minister of Uganda, visited the [[Shrine of the Bab]].<ref>{{cite magazine | title = News Items from around the World|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1962 | page =3 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=533 | issue = 380}}</ref> In 1963 Nakhjavani was elected to the [[Universal House of Justice]],<ref name="ali"/> the governing body of the worldwide Bahá'í community, while Olinga chaired the first [[Bahá'í World Congress]] which announced the election to the world.<ref name="enoch"/> By the end of 1963 there were 554 [[Local Spiritual Assemblies]] in various localities, 389 smaller Bahá'í groups, and some 200 isolated individual Bahá'ís spread across Uganda.<ref name="stats"/> In 1964 the regional Assemblies were reassigned and Uganda joined with the [[Central African Republic]].<ref name="sum"/> The July 1964 issue of [[New Vision|Uganda Argus]] profiled the religion as well as a broad article about the 4 [[Bahá'í House of Worship|Bahá'í Houses of Worship]] then in existence.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Baha'i in the News|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1964 | page =16 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=06&page=48| issue = 403}}</ref> One hundred thirty-two delegates and visitors assembled in Kampala, Uganda, for the 1966 convention to elect the regional national assembly of Uganda and Central Africa.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Kampala Convention Announces House of Justice Approval for Institute Design|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1966 | page =7 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=06&page=399 | issue = 425}}</ref> Olinga was able to visit Uganda again from October to December 1967 for an extended tour of the country.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = International News Briefs|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1967 | page =9 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=06&page=549 | issue = 432}}</ref> Rapid expansion of the religion in the late 1960s was most particularly true in Uganda, [[Bahá'í Faith in Vietnam|Vietnam]] and [[Indonesia]].<ref name="survey">{{Cite journal | last = Smith | first = Peter | authorlink = Peter Smith (Bahá'í) | last2 = Momen | first2 = Moojan | author2-link = Moojan Momen | title = The Baha'i Faith 1957–1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | journal = Religion | volume = 19 | issue = 01 | pages = 63–91 | year = 1989 | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957-1988 | doi = 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8 | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> The 1968 membership of the regional national assembly of Uganda and Central Africa was: Hassan Sabri, Tito Wanantsrusri, Kolonerio Oule, Elizabeth Olinga, George William Ebetu, Moses Senoga, Sospateri Isimai, Alinote Colleque, and Albert Ocnamodek.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Uganda and Central Africa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1968 | page =11 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=07&page=191 | issue = 450}}</ref> During the period of [[Ayyám-i-Há]] 1969 the Bahá'ís had a public exhibit on the religion at the Kamapala national theatre.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Mayor of Kampala Speaks at First Baha'i Exhibit|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1969 | page =17 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=07&page=385| issue = 450}}</ref> The mayor of Kampala spoke at the opening preceding the showing of the film, "And His Name Shall Be One". The exhibit consisted of books, charts, artifacts, photographs, movies, slides, and recordings. Original Tablets, books, and excerpts written by the Báb, Bahá'u'lláh, and `Abdu'l-Bahá were displayed along with secondary works. Bahá'í history was illustrated in a chart depicting events from the birth of Bahá'u'lláh to the founding of the Universal House of Justice, plus displays of [[The Dawn-Breakers]] in three languages. The arts were shown in oil paintings, photographs, silverwork, and handwoven carpets and the diversity of nationalities and religious backgrounds was illustrated with photographs and slides taken during conventions, Temple dedications, and intercontinental conferences. Later that summer Ruhiyyih Khanum visited Uganda on a ten-day tour. In Kampala she was able to attend several events before driving into the countryside to visit Bahá'ís. In town events included: a reception given in her honor and that of two visiting members of the Universal House of Justice, Hushmand Fatheazam and 'Ali Nahkjavani; to deliver a public lecture in the hall of the national theater; to be interviewed for a full half hour on Radio Uganda on the "Guest of the Week" program; and attend a wedding at the temple along with fellow Hands of the Cause Enoch Olinga and Músá Bánaní before going on to Ethiopia and other countries on a four-month tour. She returned at the end of the tour for a few days of low key meetings with Bahá'ís before her final departure.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = 'Amatu'l-Bahá Ruhiyyih Khanum tours Tanzania, Kenya, Ethiopia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1970 |pages=2–11 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=07&page=509| issue = 468}}</ref>
====Momentous changes approaching==== In 1970 Mary Collison died - together Mary and Reginald Collison had spent their last years as caretakers of the temple.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = In Memoriam |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1970 | page =3 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=07&page=651 | issue = 475}}</ref> That summer Ugandan Bahá'ís held their first national youth conference<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Uganda; First Youth Institute |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1970 | page =9 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=07&page=669| issue = 476}}</ref> and elected a national assembly just for Uganda - the first members were: Enos Epyeru, Javan Gutosi, S. M. lsimai, Moses Senoga, Julias Nambafu, Augustin Massati, Augustin Naku, and Albert Ocamodek.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = First National Spiritual Assembly of Uganda |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1970 | page =15 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=07&page=731 | issue = 479}}</ref> On the Presidency of Idi Amin in August, the Bahá'ís were among those invited to a meeting with the President. At the meeting the Bahá'ís offered a statement outlining the basic principle of the religion of obedience to government. At a follow-up meeting, Enoch Olinga represented the community at the close of a number of sessions of Religious Conferences that took place across Uganda.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Uganda-Relations with Their Government |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1971 | page =17 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=07&page=873 | issue = 485}}</ref> Soon afterwards, Músá Banání died in September after suffering a long illness and was buried on grounds of the temple in a new Bahá'í cemetery.<ref name="BN488"/> The funeral gathered together three Hands of the Cause: Enoch Olinga, A. Q. Faizi, Ruhiyyih Khanum; a member of The Universal House of Justice, Ali Nakbjavani, Violette Nakhjavani and their daughter, Bahiyyih, whose wedding took place two years ago in Kampala to Paul Adams many other Bahá'í leaders from across Africa as well as six members of the National Spiritual Assembly of Uganda; and many other Baha'is from all over Uganda and other parts of Africa.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Uganda News |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1971 | page =11 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=07&page=971| issue = 489}}</ref> Pioneers like Zylpha Mapp served development interests in Uganda in 1971-2 while working as a director of guidance at the [[Tororo#Education|Tororo Girls' School]].<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Uganda |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1972 | page =8 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=08&page=32| issue = 492}}</ref> She was on a leave of absence from the public school system from her work in the States, and was cooperating with the Uganda Ministry of Education in developing a guidance program in other schools of the nation while also began editing the Ugandan National Baha'i Newsletter. Later in 1971 then President Amin attended the celebration of the birth of Bahá'u'lláh and made complimentary remarks about the religion.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The President of Uganda |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1972 |pages=8–10 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=08&page=32| issue = 492}}</ref> These and others worked with university researchers on mental health issues as well. Efforts inside the community included noting the importance of Bahá'í elections as part of a worldwide initiative called for by the Universal House of Justice. Other projects in 1971-2 for Uganda included beautification of the cemetery, spreading the religion, and multiple youth gatherings. In 1972 Bahá'í [[Dwight W. Allen]] won an Award of Merit for helping in the establishment of the [[Tororo]] Girls' School which was transitioned to administration by the Ugandan government.<ref name="dwight">{{cite web | last = W. Allen | first = Dwight | authorlink = | title = …About Dr. Dwight W. Allen | work = [[Old Dominion University]] Professor Webpages | publisher = Dr. Dwight W. Allen | url = http://www.odu.edu/educ/dwallen/resumeallen.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2008-06-21 }}</ref> Enoch Olinga's daughter Florence began attending the Tororo school in 1972 while other youth began making trips to various communities in support of Bahá'í activities.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Uganda Youth|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1972 | page =19 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=08&page=211 | issue = 498}}</ref> In 1973 Enoch Olinga and his wife both spoke at the Tororo School while the school also had visits from other leaders of the religion.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Distinguished Visitors to Torara Girls' School|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1973 | page =17 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=08&page=424 | issue = 508}}</ref> In 1975-6 the Olingas toured parts of Uganda as well as having talks with government officials on the teachings of the religion with some of their travels covered by announcements by radio. Meanwhile, a public exhibit on the religion was held at the national museum which was covered by the now renamed [[New Vision|Voice of Uganda]] national newsletter as well as examine Bahá'í teachings.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Uganda; Mr. Olinga tours Western Province|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1976 |pages=27–8 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=09&page=240| issue = 540}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Uganda; Mr. Olinga's group tours Busoga Province|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1976 | page =17 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=09&page=315| issue = 544}}</ref> 1975 was the silver anniversary of the religion in Uganda and a celebration, commemorating it was concluded with a program in observance of [[United Nations Day]] and a reception of high-ranking official guests from other Ghana and the UN, and members of the religion who had come from some villages.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Uganda; Silver Jubilee concludes with a U.N. Day observance|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1976 | page =15 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=09&page=402 | issue = 547}}</ref> In 1976 Zylpha Mapp-Robinson, the daughter of the first African-American woman Bahá'í, who had pioneered in many places and who lived in Uganda nine years, was elected to the national spiritual assembly of Uganda in 1976.<ref name="zylpha">{{Cite news | title = Obituaries: 1950–1969 | magazine = UMass Amherst Online | publisher = [[University of Massachusetts Amherst]] | date = Spring 2002 | url = http://umassmag.com/Spring_2002/Obituaries__1950___1969_305.html | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> In June 1977 a small conference of leaders of the religion including the Olingas was held to discuss the progress of the growth of the religion. It was unusual in that even though just 52, 13 of whom were youth, were at the meeting, they received a message from the Universal House of Justice. Enoch Olinga reminded the group that Shoghi Effendi had called the Ugandan community the spiritual heart of Africa.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Uganda; Hand of the Cause Olinga discusses goals with believers|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1977 | page =15 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=09&page=587 | issue = 558}}</ref> In September the administrative institutions of the religion had been disbanded by the government along with over two dozen other groups.<ref name="BN590">{{cite magazine | title = A sacrifice to fidelity- The senseless, brutal slayings of Enoch Olinga, his wife and children|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1980 |pages=2–7 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=10&page=176 | issue = 590}}</ref> Soon the [[Uganda-Tanzania War]] broke out in 1978 and President Amin was overthrown by early 1979.
====Oppression, violence, and freedom==== As part of a sweep across several [[Sub-Saharan]] countries, the Bahá'í Faith was banned in the 1970s in several countries: [[Burundi]], 1974; [[Mali]] 1976; [[Uganda]] 1977; [[People's Republic of the Congo|Congo]], 1978; [[Bahá'í Faith in Niger|Niger]], 1978. Uganda had had the largest Bahá'í community in Africa at the time and Olinga had returned and sought the protection of the community during this difficult time when [[Idi Amin]]'s regime ruled Uganda.<ref name="enoch"/> See also [[Uganda under Idi Amin]].
<blockquote>"This was principally the result of a campaign by a number of Arab countries. Since these countries were also by this time providers of development aid, this overt attack on the Baha'is was supported by covert moves such as linking the aid money to a particular country to the action that it took against the Baha'is. This was partially successful and a number of countries did ban the Baha'is for a time. However, the Baha'is were able to demonstrate to these governments that they were not agents of [[Zionism]] nor [[Islamophobia|anti-Islamic]] and succeeded in having the ban reversed in all of these countries except Niger."<ref name="survey"/></blockquote>
It was a period of violence from 1978.<ref name="BN590"/> In March 1979 the Olinga home was robbed though the temple was undisturbed and there was a suspicious accident where Olinga's car was rammed and forced down a hill by a troop transport vehicle, where he was robbed and left for dead,<ref name="enoch"/> and Olinga's son George was disappeared for a week by soldiers of Amin.<ref name="BN590"/> Death threats perhaps simply because of his prominence came to Olinga from his home town.<ref name="BN590"/> Meanwhile, after President Amin fled in April the religion began to re-organize - there was the re-opening of the Bahá'í House of Worship again,<ref name="BN585">{{cite magazine | title = The Hand of the Cause of God Enoch Olinga 'The Father of Victories'|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1979 |issn=0195-9212 | pages =2–3 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=10&page=81 | issue = 585}}</ref> and the beginning of reforming the national assembly in August.<ref name="BN590"/> Neighbors and a garden servant boy bore witness mostly by hearing events of the execution of the Olinga family.<ref name="enoch"/><ref name="BN585"/> On the evening of Sunday, September 16, 1979, the birthday of one of Olinga's daughters and planned as a day of a family reunion of which a few could not arrive in time,<ref name="BN590"/> after 8pm local time five soldiers entered Olinga's home while one stood guard at the household gate and killed Olinga, his wife, and three of their five children. Trails of blood went from the kitchen to the back of the house and one of the children had been hurt and roughly bandaged before the family was executed. Enoch himself was killed out in the yard where he had been heard weeping after perhaps witnessing his dead family in the very same house he had joined the religion in.<ref name="BN590"/> The news was conveyed initially by the garden servant to a member of the national committee that had been appointed and then to a 79-year-old pioneer, Claire Gung, who called internationally. Ultimately news reached the Universal House of Justice while it sat in session on the 17th. All the dead were buried in the Bahá'í cemetery on the temple grounds on the 25th while civil war and terrorism continued.<ref name="BN590"/> The funeral included hundreds of Bahá'ís who could make the trip and several members of the government of Uganda.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Funeral in Uganda for Hand of Cause Enoch Olinga|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1980 |issn=0195-9212 | page =7 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=10&page=181| issue = 590}}</ref>
After the [[Uganda-Tanzania War]] and when the ban on the religion was rescinded, Ugandan Bahá'ís re-formed their National Spiritual Assembly in 1981,<ref name="sum"/> though the [[Ugandan Bush War]] dragged on. In 1982 the two primary schools the Bahá'ís had founded in 1961 were again under Bahá'í administration by February 1982.<ref name="BN611"/> More than 200 Bahá'ís and non-Bahá'ís gathered in 1983 to celebrate children and a kindergarten multi-racial nursery school established by Claire Gung<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Uganda|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1983 |issn=0195-9212 | page =16 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=10&page=938| issue = 629}}</ref> and Rex Collison died in June 1983.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Deeply grieved passing…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1983 |issn=0195-9212 | page =13 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=10&page=954| issue = 630}}</ref> Instances of hundreds of people joining the religion recurred in 1984.<ref>{{cite magazine | title =The World; Uganda|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1985 |issn=0195-9212 | page =12 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=11&page=391| issue = 650}}</ref> In about February 1985 George Olinga and Benson Kariuki gave a talk at one the primary schools about the religion about the institutions of the religion<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The World; Uganda|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1985 |issn=0195-9212 | page =16 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=11&page=335| issue = 647}}</ref> and Claire Gung died<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Deeply grieved passing…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1985 |issn=0195-9212 | page =12 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=11&page=371| issue = 649}}</ref> while the nursery she established was assumed by the national assembly and funds were allotted for the renovation of the primary schools.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Social/economic development - Number of projects growing rapidly (section on Uganda)|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1986 |issn=0195-9212 | page =6 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=11&page=577| issue = 660}}</ref> In 1986-7 Dwight W. Allen returned to Uganda and was the project coordinator for the Donors' Conference for the rehabilitation of [[Makerere University]].<ref name="dwight"/> In 1988 the community held a children's conference and was visible in a number of public events including a preferential trade exhibition at which various governmental leaders visited.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The World; Uganda|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1988 |issn=0195-9212 | page =14 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=12&page=276| issue = 685}}</ref>
==Multiplying involvements== The Ugandan Bahá'í community has been involved in a wide range of projects many of which benefit the nation while also advancing awareness of the religion. In 1989 a Bahá'í expert and businessman in using [[appropriate technology]] from Swaziland traveled through six southern and eastern African countries including Uganda training local people in the manufacture of several kinds of fence-making machines and other technologies in building, agriculture and water programs. The 10-day training courses were organized by the National Spiritual Assemblies in each of the six countries.<ref>{{cite magazine| title = The World; Swaziland |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1989 |issn=0195-9212 | page =15 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=12&page=581 | issue = 660}}</ref> In 1989 a Bahá'í Club was organized for [[Makerere University]] composed of Bahá'ís and non-Bahá'ís<ref>{{cite magazine| title = The World; Uganda |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1990 |issn=0195-9212 | page =14 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=12&page=671 | issue = 705}}</ref> while the national assembly invited members of the Department of Religious Studies at Makerere University to the Bahá'í House of Worship to familiarize staff with the religion, its institutions and how they function to contextualize the interaction between the agencies of the religion and the university while it implemented two new courses designed and taught by a Bahá'í, Dr. Tim Rost, on "Peace and Justice" and another on "Religion and Development."<ref>{{cite magazine| title = The World; Uganda |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1990 |issn=0195-9212 | page =12 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=12&page=691 | issue = 705}}</ref> At the same time Bahá'í women of [[Mbale]] took part in events organized by the National Council on Women by a multicultural children's program emphasizing good neighborliness and handicrafts of women - government administrators observed that Bahá'ís had several programs advancing diverse issues in Uganda.<ref>{{cite magazine| title = The World; Uganda |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1990 |issn=0195-9212 | page =12 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=12&page=803| issue = 712}}</ref> In 1990 the Bahá'í Office of Social and Economic Development in Uganda established a project to train healthcare field workers for work in Uganda.<ref>{{cite magazine| title = The World; Uganda |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1990 |issn=0195-9212 | page =13 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=12&page=843| issue = 714}}</ref> In 1993 the national assembly added a project to develop a middle-level management training program for community level primary health care workers. The focus was on prevention of childhood diseases, maternal-infant health care, and community building.<ref>{{cite web | author = Canadian Baha'i International Development Agency | title = Chronological history of funded activities (xls download) | work = Canadian Baha'i International Development Agency | publisher = Canadian Baha'i International Development Agency | date = 2006-02-06 | url = http://www.cbida.ca/cbida_trackrecord.xls | accessdate = 2008-06-21}}</ref> Later, the Uganda Bahá'í Institute for Development set up a project introducing use of the latrine, immunization, and nets to fight off malaria-bearing mosquitoes, and people learned the importance of clean water in a Ugandan village.<ref>{{Cite news | last = International Community | first = Bahá'í | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | last2 = Worth | first2 = Steve | title = In Uganda, community health workers effect long term changes | periodical = One Country | volume = 11 | issue = 02 | date = July–September 1999 | url = http://www.onecountry.org/e112/e11201as.htm | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> In 2000, the Bahá'ís of Uganda shared their activities in the areas of education, family health, moral training for children, publishing, and collaboration with other non-governmental organizations at a national [[United Nations Day]] celebration held at the [[Muguluka]] Primary School near [[Jinja, Uganda|Jinja]].<ref>{{Cite news | last = International Community | first = Bahá'í | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = Baha'is take part in Uganda's national UN Day celebration | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 2000-11-10 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/76 | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> After receiving her Ph.D. at age 78, Zylpha Mapp-Robinson returned to Uganda at age 86 in the year 2000 to create the Ugandan Institution for the advancement of Women.<ref name="zylpha"/> In 2002 a National Conference in [[Guyana]] on "Spiritual Approach to the Challenge of HIV/AIDS" sponsored by the Varqa Foundation, [[UNICEF]], & [[Bahá'í International Community]] highlighted experiences in Uganda dealing with the [[AIDS]] epidemic by including the role of the spiritual training of children on virtues like humility, reverence, kindliness, respect and courtesy, and unity in diversity so that they would lead moral lives and overcome not only AIDS but alcohol and drug abuse, violence, crime, prejudice, hatred, intolerance and poverty.<ref>{{Cite conference |conference=National Conference on "Spiritual Approach to the Challenge of HIV/AIDS" |url=http://www.sdnp.org.gy/varqa/varqa_reports/dec13_conference_report.html | title = Reports - Youth Can Move the World | date = 2002-12-13 | place = Guyana | publisher = Varqa Foundation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050925132728/http://www.sdnp.org.gy/varqa/varqa_reports/dec13_conference_report.html |archive-date = 25 September 2005}}</ref> In 2004 the Bahá'í-based Uganda Program of Literacy for Transformation helped participants acquire the skills, knowledge, and incentive for a “lifelong self-improvement plan” — coupled with an emphasis on moral education and inter-religious harmony.<ref>{{Cite news | last = International Community | first = Bahá'í | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = In Uganda, a focus on practical knowledge boosts literacy efforts | periodical = One Country | volume = 16 | issue = 01 | date = April–June 2004 | url = http://www.onecountry.org/e161/e16101as_Uganda_Uplift_story.htm | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref>
The Ugandan Bahá'í community has also encouraged the practice of the arts. Eighteen youth from Kenya, Uganda, [[Ethiopia]], and [[Tanzania]] joined together to form Youth in Motion, a Bahá'í Workshop (see [[Oscar DeGruy]]) aimed at expressing the message brought by [[Bahá'u'lláh]]. The group traveled for four months, performing before a total of more than 50,000 people in three countries.<ref>{{cite web | last = International Community | first = Bahá'í | authorlink = Bahá'í International Community | title = Bahá'í Youth: "A New Kind of People" | work = 1994–95 edition of The Bahá'í World | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | year = 1996 | url = http://info.bahai.org/article-1-9-2-8.html | accessdate = 2008-06-21 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080617210351/http://info.bahai.org/article-1-9-2-8.html| archivedate= 17 June 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> In 1998 Bahá'í [[Margaret Nagawa]] held a showing at the Ugandan National Museum,<ref>{{Cite news | last = Nagawa | first = Margaret | title = News & Letters | periodical = Arts Dialogue | publisher = Bahá'í Association For the Arts | volume = 1999 | issue = June | year = 1999 | url = http://bahai-library.com/bafa/48.htm | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> and award-winning Bahá'í [[Edel'Akongu Ekodelele Eyperu]] died in 2002.<ref>{{Cite news | last = van Kerkhof | first = Sonja | title = Edel'Akongu Ekodelele Eyperu singer, songwriter, guitarist, Uganda | periodical = Arts Dialogue | publisher = Bahá´í Association For the Arts | volume = 2002 | issue = November | year = 2002 | url = http://bahai-library.com/bafa/e/eyperu.htm | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref>
In 2001 a week-long celebration featuring a statement by Ugandan President [[Yoweri Kaguta Museveni]], some 2000<ref>{{Cite news | last = International Community | first = Bahá'í | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = Baha'i Community of Uganda celebrates its 50th anniversary (slideshow - slide 3) | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 2001-08-05 | url = http://news.bahai.org/multimedia/slideshow.php?storyid=135 | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> of the Ugandan Baha'i community commemorated the 50th anniversary of its founding.<ref>{{Cite news | last = International Community | first = Bahá'í | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = Baha'i Community of Uganda celebrates its 50th anniversary | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 2001-08-05 | url =http://news.bahai.org/story/135 | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref>
The Bahá'ís of Uganda have continued to be involved in social issues; in 2007 a movie on development issues in Uganda was produced by the Bahá'ís named "Opening a Space - The Discourse on Science, Religion and Development in Uganda"<ref>{{Cite news | last = International Community | first = Bahá'í | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = Ugandans study approaches to development | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 2007-11-30 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/590 | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> and on 25 November 2007 the Bahá'í House of Worship was a rallying point on for the "Speak out! Stand out!" campaign on preventing violence against women.<ref>{{cite web |title = Speak out! Stand out! Commit to preventing Violence against Women |work = SMS Campaign |publisher = Women of Uganda Network |date = 2007-12-06 |url = http://www.wougnet.org/Alerts/speakoutgenderviolence.html |accessdate = 2008-06-21 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080516123838/http://www.wougnet.org/Alerts/speakoutgenderviolence.html |archivedate = 2008-05-16 |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref> Bahá'í delegates from Uganda and 14 other countries convened in New York from February 23 – March 7 for the 52nd session of the [[UN Commission on the Status of Women]] in 2008.<ref>{{Cite web | title = 52nd Session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women | year = 2008 |website=UN Women | url = https://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/csw/52sess.htm }}</ref>
Ugandan Bahá'ís have also participated in recent international Bahá'í events. Ugandan youth were among the 149 assembled at the National Bahá’í Center in [[Burundi]] in August 2006.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = International Community | first = Bahá'í | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = Youth conference in Burundi focuses on social transformation | journal = One Country | volume = 18 | issue = 02 | date = July–September 2006 | url = http://www.onecountry.org/e182/e18209as_Burundi_Youth_Conference.htm | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> In 2007 Bahá'ís in [[Entebbe]] helped organize [[World Religion Day]] commemorations.<ref>{{Cite news | last = International Community | first = Bahá'í | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = Congo Republic issues stamp for World Religion Day | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 2007-01-31 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/503 | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> In 2008 one of the delegates from Uganda was one of the 19 tellers who counted the secret ballots for the election of the Universal House of Justice.<ref>{{Cite news | last =@comcast.net | first = bradpokorny | title = Bahá'í News: In a global procession, Baha'is cast ballots for the Universal House of Justice | newspaper = Worldwide Faith News | date = 2008-04-29 | url = http://www.wfn.org/2008/04/msg00273.html | postscript =<!--None--> }}</ref>
==Demographics== During 2000–2002 estimates of the Ugandan Bahá'í community ranged widely; while the official census counted almost 19,000 Bahá'í,<ref name="Census 2002">{{cite web|url=http://www.ubos.org/onlinefiles/uploads/ubos/pdf%20documents/2002%20Census%20Final%20Reportdoc.pdf|title=2002 Uganda Population and Housing Census - Main Report|publisher=Uganda Bureau of Statistics|accessdate=2008-03-26|format=PDF}}</ref> other sources range from 66,000<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.adherents.com/largecom/com_bahai.html | publisher = Adherents.com | title = The Largest Baha'i Communities | accessdate = 2008-06-21 | date = 2005-09-30| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080604143333/http://www.adherents.com/largecom/com_bahai.html| archivedate= 4 June 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> to 105,000 Bahá'ís in the country.<ref name="philip">{{Cite news | title = Philip Hainsworth | newspaper = Telegraph.co.uk | publisher = Telegraph Media Group Limited | date = 2001-12-20 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1365926/Philip-Hainsworth.html | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> By 2005 US Dept. State statistics estimated Hinduism, the Bahá'í Faith, and Judaism together formed 2% of the national population.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51501.htm |title=Uganda |date=2005-11-08 | accessdate = 2008-06-21 |website=Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor |publisher=United States State Department}}</ref> About 300 Bahá'í believers were in Kampala.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Kakembo | first = Titus | title = Uganda: Being a Baha'i Faithful | newspaper = AllAfrica.com | publisher = New Vision | date = 2007-12-08 | url = http://allafrica.com/stories/200712100939.html | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref>
