{{Bahá'í sidebar}} The '''Bahá'í Faith in Uzbekistan''' began in the lifetime of [[Bahá'u'lláh]], the founder of the religion.{{Cite journal | last = Hassall | first = Graham | title = Notes on the Babi and Baha'i Religions in Russia and its territories | journal = Journal of Bahá'í Studies | volume = 05 | issue = 03 | pages = 41–80, 86 | year = 1993 | url =http://bahai-library.com/hassall_babi_bahai_russia | accessdate = 2010-02-18}} Circa 1918 there were an estimated 1900 Bahá'ís in [[Tashkent]]. By the period of the [[Religion in the Soviet Union#Policy toward religions in practice|policy of oppression]] of religion in the former [[Soviet Union]] the communities shrank away - by 1963 in the entire USSR there were about 200 Bahá'ís.{{cite web|author=Local Spiritual Assembly of Kyiv |title=Statement on the history of the Bahá'í Faith in Soviet Union |work=Official Website of the Bahá'ís of Kyiv |publisher=Local Spiritual Assembly of Kyiv |year=2007-8 |url=http://bahai.kiev.ua/history9.html |accessdate=2010-02-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100715093037/http://bahai.kiev.ua/history9.html |archivedate=2010-07-15 |df= }} Little is known until the 1980s when the [[Bahá'í Faith]] started to grow across the Soviet Union again.{{cite web | last = Momen | first = Moojan|authorlink= Moojan Momen | title = Russia | work = Draft for "A Short Encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith" | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | date = | url =http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_russia| accessdate = 2008-04-14}} In 1991 a Bahá'í [[National Spiritual Assembly]] of the Soviet Union was elected but was quickly split among its former members. In 1992, a regional National Spiritual Assembly for the whole of Central Asia was formed with its seat in Ashgabat. In 1994 the National Spiritual Assembly of Uzbekistan was elected.{{cite web | last = Hassall | first = Graham |author2=Universal House of Justice | title = National Spiritual Assemblies statistics 1923-1999 | work = Assorted Resource Tools | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | url =http://bahai-library.com/hassall_nsas_years_formation | accessdate = 2008-04-02}} In 2008 eight Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly|Local Spiritual Assemblies]] or smaller groups had registered with the government{{Cite journal|title=Republic of Uzbekistan |journal=Journal Islam Today |volume=1429H/2008 |issue=25 |publisher=Islamic Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization |location= |year=2008 |url=http://www.isesco.org.ma/english/publications/Islamtoday/25/p11.php |accessdate=2010-02-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090902083710/http://www.isesco.org.ma/english/publications/Islamtoday/25/p11.php |archivedate=2009-09-02 }} though more recently there were also raids{{Cite news | last = Corley | first = Felix | title = They can drink tea – that's not forbidden | newspaper = Forum 18 | date = 24 September 2009 | url = http://www.forum18.org/Archive.php?article_id=1353 | accessdate = 2010-02-18}} and expulsions.{{Cite news | last = Corley | first = Felix | title = UZBEKISTAN: Two more foreigners deported for religious activity | newspaper = Forum 18 | date = 16 February 2010 | url = http://www.forum18.org/Archive.php?article_id=1409 | accessdate = 2010-02-18}} ==History in the region== ===A part of the Russian Empire=== The earliest relationship between the Bahá'í Faith and Uzbekistan comes under the sphere of the country's [[History of Uzbekistan (1876–1991)|history with Russia]]. During that time, when the region was variously called Asiatic Russia or [[Russian Turkestan]] as part of the [[Russian Empire]], the history stretches back to 1847 when the Russian ambassador to [[Tehran]], Prince Dimitri Ivanovich Dolgorukov, requested that the [[Báb]], the herald to the Bahá'í Faith who was imprisoned at [[Maku, Iran|Maku]], be moved elsewhere; he also condemned the massacres of Iranian religionists, and asked for the release of [[Bahá'u'lláh]], the founder of the Bahá'í Faith. Within the lifetime of Bahá'u'lláh the religion was established in [[Samarkand]] to which [[Mirzá Abu'l-Fadl]] later traveled. While in Samarkand in 1892 Mirza Abu'l-Fadl wrote a book, ''Fassl-ul-Khitab'' (Conclusive Proof), in response to the questions of Mirza Haydar-Ali of Tabriz.{{Cite journal | last = ibn-Kalanter | first = Ish'te'a'l | title = Mirza Abdul-Fazl | journal = Star of the West | volume = 14 | issue = 19 | pages = 318–9 | publisher = | location = | date = March 2, 1914 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=rw4YAAAAYAAJ&lpg=RA9-PA318&ots=FXCOyKPeYI&pg=RA9-PA318#v=onepage&q=&f=false | accessdate = 2010-02-19}} It was in Samarkand, too, that he debated a Protestant preacher. In 1910 the Samarkand Bahá'í community elected its first assembly in addition to having a school, and built a center which held four meetings a week. One tablet of [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] says to the assembly of Samarkand:
Do ye know in what cycle ye are created and in what age ye exist? This is the age of the Blessed Perfection and this is the time of the Greatest Name!… If we are not happy and joyous at this season, for what other season shall we wait and for what other time shall we look? This is the time for growing; the season for joyous gathering! …{{Cite book |last = `Abdu'l-Bahá |author-link = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1909 |title = Tablets of Abdul-Baha Abbas |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Committee |place = Chicago, USA |id = | pages = 641–2 |url = http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TAB/tab-698.html }}
===Soviet period=== In [[Tashkand]], a community of Bahá'ís had expanded to about 1900 members, supporting a library, Persian and Russian language schools, and large meetings were being advertised with the permission of government authorities. Bahá'í literature published in Tashkand included several works of `Abdu'l-Bahá. By 1938, after numerous arrests and a [[Religion in the Soviet Union#Policy toward religions in practice|policy of oppression]] of religion, Bahá'ís across the Soviet Union were being sent to prisons and camps or sent abroad.{{cite conference|last=Momen |first=Moojan |authorlink=Moojan Momen |title=Turkmenistan |booktitle=draft of "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" |publisher=Bahá'í Library Online |year=1994 |url=http://www.northill.demon.co.uk/relstud/turkmnst.htm |accessdate=2008-05-21 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509200356/http://www.northill.demon.co.uk/relstud/turkmnst.htm |archivedate=9 May 2008 |deadurl=yes }} Bahá'í communities in 38 cities across Soviet territories ceased to exist. In Tashkent Bahá'ís were interrogated and imprisoned. Aqa Habibullah Baqiroff of Tashkent was sentenced to ten years imprisonment "in the neighbourhood of the North Sea and the polar forests." Following the ban on religion, the Bahá'ís, strictly adhering to their principle of obedience to legal government, abandoned its administration and its properties were nationalized.{{cite book | last = Effendi | first = Shoghi | authorlink = Shoghi Effendi | title = The World Order of Bahá'u'lláh | publisher = US Bahá’í Publishing Trust | edition = 1991 first pocket-size | date = 1936-03-11 | location = Haifa, Palestine | pages = 64–67 | url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/WOB/wob-34.html#pg64| isbn = }} By 1946 in all Turkestan only Ashgabat, Samarkand and Tashkand communities continued. Bahá'ís had managed to re-enter various countries of the [[Eastern Bloc]] through the 1950s, following a plan of the head of the religion at the time, [[Shoghi Effendi]]. By 1956 there was only a vague mention of an operating community of Bahá'ís in Uzbekistan.{{cite magazine | title = The Guardian's Message to the forty-eighth annual Baha'i Convention |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1956 | number = 303 |pages=1–2 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} A pair of small communities were listed in 1963 - [[Tashkand]] and an isolated Bahá'í in [[Fergana]].[http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63&chapter=1#22 The Bahá'í Faith: 1844-1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953-1963], Compiled by [[Hands of the Cause]] Residing in the Holy Land, page 95. The [[Universal House of Justice]], the head of the religion since 1963, then recognized small Bahá'í communities in much of the USSR: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Turkistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan. At this time in the USSR there were 200 Bahá'ís. ==Development of the community== There is evidence that the Bahá'í Faith started to grow across the [[Soviet Union]] in the 1980s. In 1990 [[Local Spiritual Assembly|Local Spiritual Assemblies]] were listed in [[Samarkand]] and Tashkent.{{cite magazine | title = Eastern Europe – Details of Two-Year Plan disclosed|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1990 | number = 712 |ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=2–3 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In 1991 a Bahá'í [[National Spiritual Assembly]] of the Soviet Union was elected but was quickly split among its former members. In 1992, a regional National Spiritual Assembly for the whole of Central Asia ([[Turkmenistan]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Kirgizia]], [[Tajikistan]], and Uzbekistan) was formed with its seat in Ashgabat. In 1994 the National Spiritual Assembly of Uzbekistan was elected. ==Modern community== In 2006 the US State Department ambassador-at-large for international religious freedom singled out Uzbekistan for criticism for its recent crackdown on religious minorities, saying the government of President [[Islam Karimov]] had stepped up restrictions.{{Cite news | title = Religious extremism global threat, U.S. warns | newspaper = The Washington Times | publisher = The Washington Times, LLC | date = September 15, 2006 | url = http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2006/sep/15/20060915-102833-2307r/ | accessdate = 2010-02-18}} However Uzbek Bahá'ís were able to attend a regional conference on the progress of the religion in [[Almaty]] in southeastern Kazakhstan in 2008.{{Cite web | title = The Almaty Regional Conference | work = Regional Conferences of the Five Year Plan | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | date = 6–7 December 2008 | url =http://news.bahai.org/community-news/regional-conferences/almaty.html | accessdate = 2010-02-18}} Two of the communities in Uzbekistan showed higher scale coordination on the efforts of the community. Three members of the National Spiritual Assembly were delegates in Haifa for international Bahá'í convention in 2008,{{Cite news | title = Delegates arrive in Haifa for International Bahá'í Convention | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | date = 27 April 2008 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/624 | accessdate = 2010-02-18}} and Uzbeks had joined the religion elsewhere.{{Cite news | title = The Kiev Regional Conference | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | date = 28 February – 1 March 2009 | url = http://news.bahai.org/community-news/regional-conferences/kiev.html | accessdate = 2010-02-18}} But in 2009-2010 registered groups had meetings that were broken up, and parents who had signed permission for their children to attend these meetings were fined. Propaganda about religious activities including those of Bahá'ís and Muslims had been forced through Uzbek cable television operators.{{Cite news | title = Uzbek cable operators forced to air propaganda | newspaper = uznews.net | publisher = uznews.net | date = 2009-10-25 | url = http://www.uznews.net/news_single.php?lng=en&sub=&cid=27&nid=11735 | accessdate = 2010-02-18| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100226031508/http://www.uznews.net/news_single.php?lng=en&sub=&cid=27&nid=11735| archivedate= 26 February 2010 | deadurl= no}} ===Demographics=== Statistics from the state Religious Affairs Committee indicate that one Baha'i community lost registration between October 2002 and February 2007.{{Cite news | title = Uzbekistan religious freedom survey, August 2008 | newspaper = Forum 18 | date = August 2008 | url = http://www.forum18.org/Archive.php?article_id=1170| accessdate = 2010-02-18}} As of 2005 there were 6 communities registered with the government{{cite web | url =https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51590.htm | title = International Religious Freedom Report Ukraine | year = 2005 | date = | accessdate = 2010-02-18 | author = ((Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor)) | publisher = United States State Department}} while in 2008 there were eight. These communities included [[Tashkent]], [[Samarkand]], [[Jizzakh]], [[Bukhara]] and [[Navoi]]. The [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying on [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]) estimated some 770 Bahá'ís in 2005.{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | doi = | accessdate = 2009-07-04}} ==See also== *[[Freedom of religion in Uzbekistan]] *[[History of Uzbekistan]] *[[List of cities in Uzbekistan]] *[[Bahá'í Faith in Kazakhstan]] *[[Bahá'í Faith in Turkmenistan]] *[[Persecution of Bahá'ís]] *[[Allegations of Bahá'í involvement with other powers]] ==Further reading== * [http://bahai-library.com/herrmann_history_bahais_samarkand Preliminary History of the Bahá'í Community of Samarkand, Uzbekistan], by Duane L. Herrmann and Hasan T. Shodiev,Baha'i Vizier, The Netherlands: 2004 Winter ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.bahai.org/worldwide-community/national-communities/uzbekistan Uzbekistan Bahá'í National Community] {{Asia topic|Bahá'í Faith in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baha'i Faith in Uzbekistan}} [[Category:Religion in Uzbekistan]] [[Category:Bahá'í Faith by country|U]]

{{refimprove|date=September 2009}} {{Infobox Former Country |native_name = ''Bisdom Dorpat'' ([[Low German language|nds]])
''Ecclesia Tarbatensis'' ([[Latin language|la]]) |conventional_long_name = Bishopric of Dorpat |common_name = Dorpat, Bishopric |continent = Europe | region = Baltic | country = Ugaunia |era = Middle Ages |status = Confederation | empire=Holy Roman Empire |status_text = [[Prince-Bishopric]] of [[Terra Mariana]] |government_type = Theocracy |year_start = 1224 |year_end = 1558 |event1 = [[Henry VII of Germany|Henry VII]] grants [[margraviate]] |date_event1 = 1 December 1225 |event_end = Livonian War |p1 = Ugaunia |image_p1 = [[File:Sin escudo.svg|20px|Image missing]] |s2 = Duchy of Livonia (1561–1621) |image_s2 = [[File:Coat of arms of Lithuania.png|20px]] |image_coat = Biskupstwo Dorpatu COA.svg|200px |image_map = Medieval Livonia 1260.svg |image_map_caption = The Bishopric of Dorpat, shown (orange, upper right) within the [[Livonian Confederation]], 1260 |capital = [[Tartu|Dorpat (Tartu)]], from 1224 |latd=58 |latm=23 |latNS=N |longd=26 |longm=43 |longEW=E |common_languages = [[Low German language|Low German]], [[Estonian language|Estonian]] |religion = Roman Catholicism |leader1 = Hermann von Buxhövden |leader2 = [[Hermann II of Dorpat|Hermann Wesel]] |year_leader1 = 1224–48 |year_leader2 = 1552–60 |title_leader = Prince-Bishop }} The '''Bishopric of [[Tartu|Dorpat]]''' ({{lang-et|Tartu piiskopkond}}; {{lang-nds|Bisdom Dorpat}}; {{lang-la|Ecclesia Tarbatensis}}) was a medieval [[prince-bishopric]], i;e; both a [[diocese]] of the [[Roman Catholic Church]] and a temporal principality ruled by the bishop of the diocese. It existed from 1224 to 1558, generally encompassing what are now [[Tartu County]], [[Põlva County]], [[Võru County]], and [[Jõgeva County]] in [[Estonia]]. The prince-bishopric was a sovereign member of the [[Holy Roman Empire]] (formally from 6 Nov 1225) and part of the [[Livonian Confederation]]. == History == [[File:Tartu Toomkiriku varemed 2012.jpg|thumb|left|[[Tartu Cathedral]], today in ruins, was the seat of the Bishop of Dorpat ([[Tartu]]).]] The first Bishop of Dorpat (the current [[Tartu]]) was [[Hermann of Dorpat|Hermann von Buxhövden]], the brother of [[Albert of Riga|Albert von Buxhövden]], [[Bishop of Riga]] and leader of the [[Livonian Crusade]]. The Estonian Diocese was established by the Bishop of Riga in 1211 and its first nominal seat was [[Lihula|Leal (Lihula)]] in western Estonia. In 1224, Bishop Hermann took possession of parts of what is today southeastern Estonia and chose Dorpat as his new seat. On 6 November 1225 he was enfeoffed with his principality by [[Henry VII of Germany]], [[King of the Romans]], and on 1 December Dorpat was created a [[March (territorial entity)|March]] of the Holy Roman Empire.{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}} The principality was founded mainly on territories of the [[Ugaunia]]n tribe of ancient [[Estonia]]ns. In 1242, Bishop Hermann with his Ugaunian subjects was defeated by [[Novgorod Republic|Novgorod]]'s prince [[Alexander Nevsky]] in the famous [[Battle on Lake Peipus]]. During 1268, Fredrik, the then Bishop of Dorpat, is known to have called himself also as the "Bishop of [[Karelia]]", the background of the short-lived title remaining open.{{cite web|url=http://193.184.161.234/DF/detail.php?id=137|title=Excerpt from sources|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927051242/http://193.184.161.234/DF/detail.php?id=137|archivedate=2007-09-27}}. In Latin. Hosted by the [http://www.narc.fi National Archive of Finland]. See {{cite web |url=http://www.narc.fi/Arkistolaitos/sahkoiset/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-05-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070608003759/http://www.narc.fi/Arkistolaitos/sahkoiset/ |archivedate=2007-06-08 |df= }} and ''Diplomatarium Fennicum'' from the menu. The Bishopric of Dorpat was an important [[Hanseatic League|Hanseatic]] trade center. At the end of the 14th century, former Dietrich Damerow became the Bishop of Dorpat. He was the archenemy of the [[Livonian Order]] and made a coalition against it with [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania|Lithuania]], [[Duchy of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Mecklenburg]], and the [[Victual Brothers]] (notorious pirates of the [[Baltic Sea]]). He even asked King [[Richard II of England]] to take Dorpat under his protection. The Order invaded the bishopric in 1379 with no success. After settling the conflict the Livonian Order lost its right to demand that vassals of bishoprics take part in military campaigns. During its last years, the Bishopric of Dorpat had a dispute with Russia which became later the main pretext of the [[Livonian War]]. Tsar [[Ivan the Terrible]] demanded that the bishopric pay a huge tribute of 40,000 talers. Ivan insisted that the Dorpat was the ancient Russian fortress of ''Yuryev'' (referring to short-term Ruthenian rule of the area after conquest by prince [[Yaroslav I the Wise]], 1030–61(?)). The rulers of Dorpat tried to negotiate a smaller amount in the interest of extending the truce, but Ivan dismissed the diplomats and started the war. In 1558 Tartu was conquered by Russian troops and the Bishopric of Dorpat ceased to exist. Beside Dorpat (Tartu) there were five more stone castles in the Bishopric: * [[Otepää|Odenpäh]] ({{lang-et|Otepää}}) as the ancient centre of Ugandi and the first stone stronghold of bishopric; * [[Kirumpää|Kirrumpäh]] (''Kirumpää'') and [[Vastseliina|Neuhausen]] (''Vastseliina'') by the important ancient Dorpat–Pleskau (Tartu–Pihkva) road; * Oldentorn (Vana-Kastre) and Warbeke or Caster (Uue-Kastre) by the [[Emajõgi]] river which runs from Dorpat to [[Lake Peipus]]. There was also an outstanding [[Cistercian]] monastery, [[Kärkna Abbey]] (also Valkena or Falkenau) near Dorpat. == The former Bishopric today == The center of the bishopric was the Tartu (Dorpat) castle ({{lang-et|[[Toomemägi]]}}). The castle was damaged during the Northern War and was dismantled during the 18th century. Later (at the beginning of 19th century) an observatory was built on the site. The seat of the bishopric, [[Tartu Cathedral|Dorpat Cathedral]], was damaged during the [[Protestant Reformation]] and has been in ruins since the 17th century. == Bishops of Dorpat == *[[Hermann of Dorpat|Hermann von Buxhöwden]] 1224–48 *Alexander 1263–68 *Friedrich von Haseldorf 1268–88 *Bernhard I 1289–1302 *Dietrich I Vyshusen 1302–12 *Nikolaus 1312–23 *Engelbert von Dolen 1323–41 *Wescelus 1342–1344 *Johannes I Viffhusen 1346–73 *Heinrich I von Velde 1373–78 *Dietrich II Damerow 1378–1400 *Heinrich II Wrangel 1400–10 *Bernhard II Bülow 1410–13 *Dietrich III Resler 1413–41 *Bartholomäus Savijerwe 1441–59 *Helmich von Mallinckrodt 1459–68 *Andreas Pepler 1468–73 *Johannes II Bertkow 1473–85 *Dietrich V Hake 1485–98 *Johannes III von der Rope 1499–1505 *Gerhard Schrove 1505–13 *Johannes IV Duesborg 1513–14 *Christian Bomhower 1514–18 *Johannes V Blankenfeld 1518–27 *Johannes VI Bey 1528–43 *Jodokus von der Recke 1544–51 *[[Hermann II of Dorpat|Hermann II Wesel]] 1552–60 == References == {{Reflist}} {{Refimprove|date=May 2007}} == Sources and external links == * World Statesmen [http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Estonia.html#Dorpat Estonia: Prince-bishopric of Dorpat (Tartu)] * GigaCatholic [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/former/dorp0.htm Diocese of Dorpat] {{DEFAULTSORT:Dorpat, 1224 Bishopric}} [[Category:1558 disestablishments]] [[Category:States and territories established in 1224]] [[Category:Former Roman Catholic dioceses in Europe]] [[Category:Pre-Reformation dioceses in Nordic Europe]] [[Category:Roman Catholic bishops by diocese]] [[Category:Medieval Estonia]] [[Category:Geographic history of Estonia]] [[Category:Prince-Bishoprics of Livonia]] [[Category:13th-century establishments in Estonia]] [[Category:History of Tartu]]

revision.text:
{{Religious text primary|date=September 2011}} [[File:Captain Moroni by Josh Cotton.jpg|thumb|An artist's impression of Captain Moroni, commander of the Nephite forces from approximately 74–56 BC. Digital sculpture by Josh Cotton.|upright=1.5]]
{{Book of Mormon}}
According to the [[Book of Mormon]], '''Captain Moroni''' was an important [[Nephite]] military commander and patriot who lived during the 1st century BC. He is perhaps best known for raising a "title of liberty" as a call to arms for his people to defend their country, family, freedom, peace, and religion.<ref>{{Sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Alma|chapter=43|verse=12}}</ref> He is first mentioned in the [[Book of Alma]] as "the chief captain over the Nephites."<ref>{{Sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Alma|chapter=43|verse=16}}</ref>
Captain Moroni is presented as a righteous and skilled military commander. Among his accomplishments were his extensive preparations for battle and his fierce defense of the right of the Nephites to govern themselves and worship as they saw fit.
Captain Moroni shares a name with the [[Moroni (Book of Mormon prophet)|prophet Moroni]]; the former is indexed<ref>[http://scriptures.lds.org/in/contents Index<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> in the [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|LDS]] edition of the Book of Mormon as '''Moroni<sup>1</sup>.''' ==Early command== According to the Book of Mormon, Moroni was "only twenty and five years old when he was appointed chief captain" of the Nephites.<ref>{{Sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Alma|chapter=43|verse=16|range=-17}}</ref> The appointment came in response to a looming war with [[Lamanites]] and [[Zoramites]], a force which was led by [[Zerahemnah]] and included many Nephite dissenters. The Lamanite army attacked the Nephites in the land of Jershon and the battle ended on the banks of the river Sidon. In this war, Moroni set to work readying the Nephite people with [[body armor]] for the first time. He sent spies to investigate the Lamanites' weaknesses, and then he led his troops with the plan to surround those of the Lamanites. Moroni's overriding objective was to defend his people and their right to worship their God as they pleased. Ultimately, Moroni met that objective, which resulted in keeping many of the Lamanites from ever coming to combat against the Nephites again.
Moroni introduced to the Nephites revolutionary strategies in military tactics, safety, and precaution. He kept the people physically safe while he prayed, guiding and leading his armies by divine intervention. He was also known by his people for his firm ideology and integrity and his constant willingness to support the causes of personal freedom gaining the people's trust.
==Title of liberty== [[File:Moroni - Book of Mormon.jpg|thumb|400px|Captain Moroni raises the "Title of Liberty", as found in the 1910 book ''Cities in the Sun''.]] Moroni is associated with the "title of liberty," a standard that he raised to rally the Nephites to defend their liberties from a group of dissenters who wanted to establish their leader as a king. Moroni was so angry with [[Amalickiah]]'s dissention and wicked influence that he tore his coat and wrote upon it, "In memory of our God, our religion, and freedom, and our peace, our wives, and our children."<ref>{{Sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Alma|chapter=46|verse=10|range=-12}}</ref> With those words, he rallied his people to defend their families and their freedom and drove out the armies of Amalickiah. Moroni put to death any dissenters who did not flee and would not support the cause of freedom, and his " title of liberty" was raised over every Nephite tower.<ref>{{Sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Alma|chapter=46|verse=35|range=-36}}</ref>
According to the Book of Mormon, Moroni sought to strengthen the Nephites spiritually to be better prepared against the Lamanites, leading [[Mormon (prophet)|Mormon]] to comment on Moroni's righteousness. <ref>{{Sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Alma|chapter=48|verse=16|range=-18}}</ref>
==King-men==<!-- This section is linked from [[Book of Alma]] --> Years later, Moroni encountered problems with a group of men called "[[king-men]]," who were so called because they wanted to replace the chief judge and democracy with a king, an aim seen as destroying the liberty of the people. Moroni had written to [[Pahoran]] for help in the war, and the Lamanites attacked before the help could arrive. Moroni wrote again, chastising Pahoran in the process for failing to respond, even threatening to "stir up insurrections" against what he perceived to be the non-responsive government authorities. <ref>{{Sourcetext|source=Book of Mormon|book=Alma|chapter=60|verse=27}}</ref> Pahoran wrote back, saying that the king-men had driven him from the judgment seat, and he had been unable to respond to Moroni's requests for assistance. Moroni left command of his armies in the hands of his deputies and led an insurrection of the people against the king-men. The leader of the king-men, [[Pachus]], was killed and his followers were taken prisoner. Moroni and Pahoran regained control of the city of Nephihah, which they had lost, restoring the previous form of government by judges.
==Retirement== After fortifying the Nephites' lands, Moroni transferred command of his armies to his son [[Moronihah]] and permanently retired to his own home. Four years later, in the 36th year of the reign of the judges (or approximately 56 BC), Moroni died. According to the chronology of years, listing the time from when Moroni took command of the armies at 25, he would have been approximately 45 when he died.
==Significance in modern Mormon culture== The narrative of Captain Moroni plays a significant role in how members of the LDS Church understand and justify the political realities of war and violence.<ref name="EOM">{{citation |last= Wood |first= Robert S. |contribution= War and Peace |contribution-url= http://eom.byu.edu/index.php/War_and_Peace |editor1-last= Ludlow |editor1-first= Daniel H |editor1-link= Daniel H. Ludlow |title= [[Encyclopedia of Mormonism]] |year= 1992}}</ref> In this context, important aspects of Moroni’s narrative include that he "did not delight in the shedding of blood," his warfare was strictly defensive, he sought the guidance of prophets before battle, and he did not seek for power.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nibley |first=Hugh |title=Leaders to Managers: The Final Shift |journal=Dialogue: A Journal of Mormon Thought |year=1983 |volume=16 |issue=4 |pages=12-21|url=https://www.dialoguejournal.com/wp-content/uploads/sbi/articles/Dialogue_V16N04_14.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Firmage |first=Edwin B. |title=Violence and the Gospel: The Teachings of the Old Testament, the New Testament, and the Book of Mormon |journal=BYU Studies |year=1985 |volume=25 | issue=1 | pages=31-53 |url=https://journals.lib.byu.edu/spc/index.php/BYUStudies/article/viewFile/5456/5106}}</ref><ref name="EOM"/> When the U.S.-led [[War in Afghanistan (2001–14)|War in Afghanistan]] commenced during the LDS Church's October 2001 [[General Conference (LDS Church)|General Conference]], [[Gordon B. Hinckley]] announced commencement and referenced the story of Captain Moroni saying, "There are times when we must stand up for right and decency, for freedom and civilization, just as Moroni rallied his people in his day to the defense of their wives, their children, and the cause of liberty."<ref>{{cite journal |last=Jenkins |first=Ryan |title="Peaceable Followers of Christ" in Days of War and Contention |journal=Religious Educator |volume=10 |issue=3 |pages=87-102 |url=https://ojs.lib.byu.edu/spc/index.php/RelEd/article/viewFile/2359/2196}}</ref>
Some Mormon authors, such as [[Nicholeen Peck]], have drawn comparisons between the lives of Captain Moroni and General [[George Washington]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Peck|first1=Nicholeen|title=“Give Me [Tree Bark], Or Give Me Death”: Liberty Yesterday And Today|url=http://ldsmag.com/article-1-8302/|website=Meridian Magazine|accessdate=30 January 2016}}</ref> Peck writes, "Many many years before George Washington, Captain Moroni did the same thing George Washington did. He wrote the Title of Liberty, and put on his military uniform, to show he would fight for his liberties if it was necessary." Mormon writer Heather Hemingway makes similar observations by noting, "Captain Moroni’s humility and valor is similar to that of George Washington during the winter of 1777-1778."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hemingway|first1=Heather|title=America and the Price of Freedom|url=http://blog.chron.com/mormonvoice/2014/06/america-and-the-price-of-freedom/|website=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=30 January 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160229123231/http://blog.chron.com/mormonvoice/2014/06/america-and-the-price-of-freedom/|archivedate=29 February 2016|df=}}</ref>
==Modern references by anti-government activists== In the Book of Mormon, Moroni is a military leader who takes command of an oppressed people and battles a corrupt king for their freedom.<ref name="Krule">{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2016/01/05/why_ammon_bundy_calls_himself_captain_moroni.html|title=The Mormon Warrior the Bundys Revere Actually Wanted the Government to Do More|work=Slate|date=January 5, 2016|accessdate=January 29, 2016|first=Miriam|last=Krule}}</ref> Moroni was a righteous general who among many notable accomplishments became angry with his government over its "indifference concerning the freedom of [its] country."<ref>https://www.buzzfeed.com/jimdalrympleii/heres-what-you-need-to-understand-about-mormon-history-if-yo#.xvBPKv2pj</ref> [[Cliven Bundy]], an anti-government activist and a Mormon, has frequently made references to the Book of Mormon in his conflicts with the [[US government]].<ref name="Krule"/> According to Oregon Public Broadcasting, during the Bundy family’s 2014 occupation of federally-owned lands in Nevada, Bundy used banners quoting Moroni: "In memory of our God, our religion, and freedom, and our peace, our wives, and our children."<ref name="Krule"/>
In 2016, [[Ammon Bundy]], a son of Cliven, used much of the same language as his father, "mixing Mormon religious symbolism with a disgust of the federal government," during an [[occupation of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge]]. One member of Bundy's anti-government extremist group refused to give any other name to the press than "Captain Moroni, from Utah."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/updates/why-the-bundy-militia-mixes-mormon-symbolism-with-anti-government-sentiment/|title=Why the Bundy militia mixes Mormon symbolism with anti-government sentiment|work=PBS NewsHour|date=January 4, 2016|accessdate=January 28, 2016|first=John|last=Sepulvado}}</ref> The man calling himself "Captain Moroni" was later identified in media reports and a criminal complaint as 34-year-old Dylan Anderson.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wweek.com/2016/01/28/captain-moroni-arraigned-in-portland/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160201063728/http://www.wweek.com/2016/01/28/captain-moroni-arraigned-in-portland/|archivedate=February 1, 2016|title=Captain Moroni Arraigned in Portland|date=January 28, 2016|work=[[Willamette Week]]|accessdate=January 30, 2016|first=Aaron|last=Mesh|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>
On January 4, 2016, the LDS Church released a statement, distancing itself from the standoff at the wildlife refuge.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Church Responds to Inquiries Regarding Oregon Armed Occupation |url = http://www.mormonnewsroom.org/article/church-responds-to-inquiries-regarding-oregon-armed-occupation |work = The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|date = January 4, 2016|accessdate = January 28, 2016}}</ref>

In [[Greek mythology]], the name '''Chryse''' ({{lang-grc|Χρύση}} or {{lang|grc|Χρυσῆ}} "golden") may refer to:
*Chryse, daughter of [[Almus (son of Sisyphus)|Almus]], a lover of [[Ares]] and mother of [[Phlegyas]].<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], ''Description of Greece'', 9. 36. 1</ref> *Chryse, a [[nymph]] or minor goddess of [[Lemnos]] (or of [[Chryse Island]]) who lured [[Philoctetes]] away from his companions which resulted in him being bitten by a snake.<ref>[[Hyginus]], ''Fabulae'', 102</ref> Some sources state that Chryse was a local epithet of [[Athena]], and the misfortune happened to Philoctetes next to her altar, which the snake was guarding.<ref>[[Sophocles]], ''Philoctetes'', 1327</ref><ref>[[Tzetzes]] on [[Lycophron]], 911</ref> The altar was said to have been set up by [[Jason]].<ref>[[Philostratus the Younger]], ''Images'', 17</ref> *Chryse, daughter of [[Pallas (son of Lycaon)|Pallas]] and consort of [[Dardanus (son of Zeus)|Dardanus]].<ref>[[Dionysius of Halicarnassus]], ''Roman Antiquities'', 1. 68. 3</ref> *Chryse, daughter of Timander, sister of Eurytione, Hellotis and Cottyto, from [[Corinth]].<ref>[[Scholia]] on [[Pindar]], ''Olympian Ode'' 13. 56b. See [[Eurythemis]] for an alternate version.</ref> *Chryse, a surname of [[Aphrodite]] on [[Lesbos]].<ref>[[Scholia]] on [[Homer]], ''[[Iliad]]'', 3. 64</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox book | italic title = <!--(see above)--> | name = Faith versus fact : why science and religion are incompatible | image = Faith vs. Fact Why Science and Religion are Incompatible.jpg| image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = [[Jerry Coyne|Jerry A Coyne]] | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = | series = | release_number = | subject = | genre = | set_in = | publisher = Viking (a division of Penguin Random House) | publisher2 = | pub_date = 2015 | english_pub_date = | published = | media_type = | pages = 311 | awards = | isbn = 978-0-670-02653-1 | isbn_note = | oclc = 919481537 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = }}
'''''Faith Versus Fact: Why Science and Religion are Incompatible''''' is a 2015 book by biologist [[Jerry Coyne]] concerning the relationship between science and religion. Coyne argues that religion and science are incompatible, by surveying the history of science and stating that both religion and science make claims about the universe, yet only science is open to the fact that it may be wrong.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tayler|first1=Jeffrey|title=Can Religion and Science Coexist?|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2015/07/religion-science-coexist-faith-versus-fact-coyne/396362/|website=TheAtlantic.Com|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=24 February 2017}}</ref>
Coyne was astonished that after having published his book, ''Why Evolution is True'', the proportion of creationists in America still remained between 40-46%. He felt that [[faith]] was the reason that kept them from accepting the facts and [[Evidence of common descent|evidence for evolution]].<ref name="kirkus">{{cite web|title=Faith Versus Fact|url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/jerry-a-coyne/faith-versus-fact/|website=www.kirkusreviews.com|publisher=Viking|accessdate=28 February 2017}}</ref>
==Synopsis== Coyne defines science as "a collection of methods" which yield knowledge which may be rejected or confirmed via testing. With this definition in hand, he went on to argue that religion and science were inherently incompatible "because they have different methods of getting knowledge about reality, different ways of assessing the reliability of that knowledge, and, in the end, arrive at conflicting conclusions about the universe."<ref name="FvF">{{cite book|last1=Coyne|first1=Jerry|title=Faith versus Fact: Why Science are Incompatible|date=2015|publisher=Penguin Books|location=New York|isbn=9780698195516|page=64}}{{rp|64}}</ref> He believes that theistic religions make claims which conflict with science in three ways: methodology, outcomes, and philosophy.<ref name="FvF" /> A substantial portion of his book criticizes [[theistic evolution]], arguing that if [[God]] were to use evolution as a method of creation the evolutionary process should show signs of directionality.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Schloss|first1=Jeffrey|title='Faith vs. Fact:' why religion and science are mutually incompatible|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/science-and-theology/2015/08/03/77136504-19ca-11e5-bd7f-4611a60dd8e5_story.html|website=TheWashingtonPost|publisher=WashingtonPost|accessdate=24 February 2017}}</ref>
==Reception== [[Kirkus Reviews]] lauded the book as "important...[it] deserves an open-minded readership." They add, "although he makes a clear and cogent argument, he may find that, once again, he is preaching to his own choir."<ref name="kirkus" />
Rau Olson of ''Booklist Online'' wrote, "none of [the New atheists] makes the case for the final divorce of religion and science, with permanent restraining orders against harassment and stalking of science by religion, better than Coyne".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Olson|first1=Ray|title=Faith vs. Fact: Why Science and Religion Are Incompatible.|url=https://www.booklistonline.com/Faith-vs-Fact-Why-Science-and-Religion-Are-Incompatible-Jerry-A-Coyne/pid=7446785|website=www.booklistonline.com|publisher=American Library Association|accessdate=28 February 2017}}</ref>
Some reviewers felt the book did not make a very strong case for why religion and science could not co-exist. Biologist Austin L. Hughes wrote for conservative magazine ''[[The New Atlantis (journal)|The New Atlantis]]'': "what Coyne is attempting in Faith Versus Fact falls under the general heading of philosophy. But his philosophical training seems inadequate to the task, since he fails to develop a consistent terminology and to construct arguments with any degree of rigor." He feels that Coyne's arguments attempting to show that doubt is necessary, or endemic, to science eventually fall on themselves, writing, "but if we push our doubt far enough, won't we eventually end up doubting even science?"<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hughes|first1=Austin L.|title=Faith, Fact, and False Dichotomies|journal=The New Atlantis|date=2015|volume=45|pages=111–117|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/faith-fact-and-false-dichotomies|accessdate=28 February 2017}}</ref>
Science writer [[John Horgan]] wrote a highly critical review of the book in [[Scientific American]] stating that, "Mr. Coyne repeatedly reminds us that science, unlike religion, promotes self-criticism, but he is remarkably lacking in this virtue himself. He rejects complaints that some modern scientists are guilty of 'scientism,' which I would define as excessive trust—faith!—in science. Actually, ''Faith vs. Fact'' serves as a splendid specimen of scientism. Mr. Coyne disparages not only religion but also other human ways of engaging with reality. The arts, he argues, 'cannot ascertain truth or knowledge,' and the humanities do so only to the extent that they emulate the sciences. This sort of arrogance and certitude is the essence of scientism."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Horgan|first1=John|title=Book by Biologist Jerry Coyne Goes Too Far in Denouncing Religion, Defending Science|url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/cross-check/book-by-biologist-jerry-coyne-goes-too-far-in-denouncing-religion-defending-science/|website=Scientific American|accessdate=1 June 2015}}</ref>
